name: CMP Museum | Official Website
desc: CMP Museum is an art museum in Taichung scheduled to open at the end of 2024.
I served as lead front-end engineer, building complex architecture and utility functions for other engineers. I also handled the CMS backend and APIs and integrated them with the frontend.

Built with Nuxt 3; Lenis.js delivers smooth scrolling. The homepage banner is a p5.js canvas interaction using 24 pillar images as masks, detecting mouse position to calculate offset and scale. Bottom images can be changed via the CMS.

The homepage includes a Socket.io easter egg: visitors connect to the Socket server, share mouse coordinates, and send messages. To manage long multi-user sessions without high traffic costs, I designed a mechanism to reduce bandwidth while keeping the interaction fun. Coordinates are normalized to the current screen ratio for consistent positioning across devices.
The site also uses numerous GSAP animations, such as scroll-guided reading cues.
Functionally, there is also a search feature driven by URL queries and backend APIs.

name: SUNMAI | Official Website
desc: SUNMAI is a well-known Taiwanese beer brand brewing with local ingredients; this project rebuilt their official site.
I handled front-end development—layout, architecture, data integration, and animations. Built with Nuxt 3 and Lenis.js for smooth scrolling.

Two major animations: the homepage bi-directional infinite scroll, where each full-screen section has its own entry/exit animations. I exported animation functions to the parent component for unified control via a GSAP timeline and progress-based looping to achieve infinite up/down scrolling.

The product page lets users explore via a draggable map. On entry, products animate into a special arrangement. Because products can grow in number and screen sizes vary, I designed a calculation to always lay out an initial 5x4 grid without layout issues.

name: Taichung State Hall | City Stroll Exhibition | Socket Server | Architecture & Flow Design
desc: The Taichung State Hall City Stroll exhibition is an offline event; this exhibit was ported to a website so visitors could interact via socket.io.
With an interactive exhibition background, I designed the full experience flow and the front-end core architecture. I also designed and coded the Socket interaction core.
The exhibition runs in sessions managed by the Socket server. At each start, guest QR codes are generated; guests scan to connect and use their phones as remotes for the interactive installations.
Each installation has its own interaction—e.g., a bulletin board for entering names, webcam+canvas filters, or a GPT-powered chatbot.

All interactions are socket-based. The challenge was routing events to the right group and device when up to three guest groups run simultaneously with identical device sets. I used Socket IDs to identify devices, grouped guests/devices, and gave each device a unique code to clearly route who sent and who should receive each event.
Beyond events, I designed a session mechanism: sessions auto-start/end by time, auto-clear after ending, and include fixed flows such as countdowns and marquee events.
I built a manager console to show session QR codes, remaining time, and daily session info, and to trigger actions like force start/end.
A duplicate-login guard prevents reusing devices or remotes: unique codes check group devices, and any prior login is forced out when a new one joins.
Overall, it delivers a fully planned interactive experience and program architecture.

name: Taichung State Hall | City Stroll Exhibition – Consciousness | Website
desc: An online exhibit for the Taichung State Hall City Stroll, letting onsite visitors interact via socket.io.
Built with p5.js and a webcam for interactive effects. Users take a photo, and p5.js filters transform it into different looks.

Three filters: (1) ASCII decoding—send webcam frames to canvas, convert pixels to ASCII, and render text; (2) Blur with a shader driven by a timer to vary blur strength; (3) Color inversion with a shader to invert colors to their counterparts.
